title: This is a post about telephones
body: Remember when I said that I solved our phone crisis, and that I'd be telling you about it soon? No? Well I do, so here we go: As I mentioned in my last post about phones, The Moxie will require at least three lines to run smoothly: one for the Moxie Cinema anytime movie line, one for our standard business line, and one for our credit card transactions. Now, if these lines were being installed into a house the cost would be nominal, but since it's being used for a business we have to shell out some major cash to make things happen. According to SBC, we would have to pay between $130 and $160 PER MONTH for three lines. Do you even know how much Dr. Pepper I could buy with $130 per month? No! You do not know how much Dr. Pepper I could buy for $130 per month, Matt. And why don't you know? Because you're glib, Matt. I've studied Dr. Pepper, and you haven't. Simple as that. But what about Vonage? They offer a basic small business package for $39.99 per month, and each additional line receives a $5 discount. So if we went with Vonage, we'd be looking at roughly $110 per month. Yes it's a savings of at least $20 per month, but do you even know how much cashew chicken I could buy for $110 per month? I could buy enough to drown myself in thick brown gravy twice over! And, even if we wanted to use Vonage, it wouldn't work with our credit card machine. According to the Vonage sales associate, you MUST have a standard landline to process credit cards correctly. And just like that, our $20 in monthly savings is gone. Poof! So where does leave us? After briefly considering a network of strategically placed walkie-talkies throughout the city, I had an epiphany - you can keep the chicken crispier if you ask for the cashew sauce on THE SIDE! Amazing! Why hadn't I thought of that before?! Then, on my way to pick up cashew chicken from The Noodle House at 1406 West Sunshine (417.865.6664), I had another flash of inspiration: why don't I use Skype for the movie and business lines? By utilizing Skype's new SkypeIn feature, I can buy an incoming phone line for $36 per YEAR... that's only $3 per month. The movie line has built-in voicemail for weekly showtimes, and the business line will be forwarded directly to my computer at the theater. We'll still have to get a standard landline for our credit card machine, but that's a lot cheaper than getting THREE of them... I think. I better recheck my math. Hold on. MONTHLY CHARGES 1. Movie Line = $3.00 2. Business Line = $3.00 3. Credit Card Line = $45.00 Monthly Total: $52.00 Woo hoo! That's a monthly savings of at least $50! Do you know how many boxes of Cheerios I can buy for $50 per month? Ten or more! Of course, Skype isn't all unicorns and jelly beans... it has a dark side as well. Most notably, not being able to call OUT without incurring a smallish per minute charge. But fear not, for we have a standard landline in case of emergencies! Huzzah! But what if you need to call someone from the theater and it's not an emergency? That, my friends, is the exact reason why the Mongolians invented mobile phones (typically pronounced mo•BULL, but can also be pronounced mo•BILE if you're trying to be funny or sound British). And then guess what we get to do with our cell phone bills? Write them off as business expenditures! Woo hoo! So what was originally a personal expenditure has morphed into a business one. Amazing. Simply amazing. I bet many of you will shoot my system full of holes, but you know what? You're glib. I've researched this and you haven't, Matt. You think you might know about The Moxie phone system because you read about it on some blog, but you don't. I do, Matt. I do.
author: Dan
